, this section estab- lishes tours of duty for employees in the Office of Chief Counsel. Except as Hours of Duty explained below, the basic
-hour workweek in the Office of Chief Counsel scheduled on five days, Monday through Friday. (
) Employee lunch breaks should normally be taken within the time frame of
a.m. until
p.m. Lunch breaks should not be used at the end of the tour of duty. (
) Pursuant to
CFR §

, each office must have a system of time ac- counting. Employees are responsible for certifying that their time records are correct. Regardless of the system used in a particular office, supervisors are reminded that they must have written records showing leave approvals and provide affirmative evidence (in other words, certify) that all their (individuals whose leave they approve) have worked the proper number of hours every pay period. Such certification is accomplished by signing either a time and attendance record, a time and attendance roster, or signing in the Single Entry Time Reporting (SETR) system. Note: Sign-in and sign-out sheets are no longer used in the Office of Chief Counsel. (

) Where the opening of a Federal office is delayed for a specified number of hours due to hazardous weather or other conditions, and such delay is generally applicable to employees in a given location, the employee’s normal tour of duty will be used as a reference point to determine when the will report to work. If an employee’s regular tour of duty is 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., and the office opening is delayed two hours, the employee would be advised to report at 10:30 a.m. and would work a six-hour day (with the other two hours reported as administrative leave).

a.m. and would work a six-hour day (with the other hours reported as administrative leave). (

) When a decision is made to dismiss employees from work early because emergency or some other general or area-wide condition, all employees dismissed at the same time. The fact that one employee may have commenced work earlier than other employees on that day will not be into consideration in authorizing an early dismissal. (
) There are two main work schedule options in the Office of Chief Counsel. Employees can only use one of the following separate systems: (cid:

When a decision is made to dismiss employees from work early because of an emergency or some other general or area

wide condition, all employees will be dismissed at the same time. The fact that one employee may have commenced work earlier than other employees on that day will not be taken into consideration in authorizing an early dismissal.
Core time in the Office of Chief Counsel is defined as 10:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. (See Exhibit 30.4.7-1, Tour of Duty Chart, Core Hours and Flexible Band.)
Personnel Administration, Training, Equal Employment Opportunity (

) The flexitour with credit hours option divides the workday into core time (see above) and flexible time. Under the flexitour program, each employee must present during core time (except for the usual lunch break), and the must work the regular number of hours each day, i.e., an eight hour day (excluding lunch) and a

-hour week in the case of a full-time employee. Beyond these minimal requirements, the precise working hours of each employee may be established individually under the procedures as below. Except in those instances where annual, sick, or other approved is granted, an employee is required to work an
hour tour of duty. (

) Employees must have schedules which are established in advance and it is not permissible under these procedures for an employee to work ten hours day and six the next in order to average eight hours for each day. Although flexible work schedule provides an employee a measure of control over their own working hours, a flexitour with credit hours schedule in no way affects employee’s right to use annual or sick leave and does not change the sor’s authority to approve the scheduling of leave. (
) Employees may, with supervisory approval, work within a time frame of
a.m.—

) With supervisory approval, an employee may earn credit hours under the flexitour with credit hours option. All credit hours must be worked within Counsel’s flexible band which is
a.m. to
p.m. Hours (

) Credit hours earned and used are processed through the personnel/payroll system, but are not reflected on employee’s leave and earnings statement; therefore, accurate record keeping is extremely important. (
) Credit hours elected by employees on flexible schedules to be worked between
p.m. and
a.m. are not subject to premium pay provisions

) No more than four credit hours can be earned in one workday but the hours not need to be contiguous with an employee’s tour of duty. For example, an employee could work her regular tour of duty from
a.m. to
p.m. then return to the office and (with management approval) work four credit hours from
p.m. to
p.m. (
) A maximum of
credit hours may be earned on each non-workday. (
) Credit hours worked must normally be requested and approved in advance writing. One method of doing so is via Form

, Request for Credit/Comp Hours, although individual supervisors have the discretion to use a different system. The use of credit hours is approved under the same provisions as annual leave. (See CCDM
, Annual Leave.) Credit hours should be taken before annual leave except in use-or-lose leave situations. (
) Credit hours may be earned and used in
-minute increments. (
) By statute, only
credit hours can be carried over each pay period. If an employee enters a pay period with
credit hours and works additional hours during that pay period, then the employee must use the additional by the end of that pay period. Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.

Schedules
) Credit hours do not have to be used within a certain period and can be over into the next leave year. (
) The
option is a bi-weekly pay period schedule consisting of nine workdays and one day off. Eight workdays are
hours and one workday (Compressed Work

work schedule may elect a starting time between

option have a work schedule that has them present at work during the daily core hours of
a.m. to
p.m. for each of the nine workdays. (
) By statute, credit hours cannot be earned under this election. (
) An employee taking annual or sick leave on a regularly scheduled
-hour must be charged nine hours leave for that day. (
) An “off” day can only be substituted within the same pay period, and all requests should be carefully considered. (
) Conflicts for “off” days are resolved by an employee’s service computation date. (

) If an employee’s “off” day falls on an official holiday, the “off” day remains same, but the employee takes the preceding workday off as an in-lieu of holiday. Example: If the holiday is on a Monday, the employee gets the preceding off. (
) Members of the Senior Executive Service (SES) may not elect a
schedule and may not earn credit hours. Work Schedule (
) Executives who are SES members may work a variable work schedule. for SES variable work schedule option permits SES members to complete their biweekly work hour requirement in less than

workdays (excluding vary their times of arrival and departure, and/or vary the number of hours worked each day, (e.g. an executive anticipates that it will be necessary to work on a Saturday and/or a Sunday to deliver a critical project timely, that executive can email his/her manager describing the necessity to work and request approval of a variable work schedule). (
) The variable work schedule allows for a temporary variation in work only and should generally be granted for no more than one pay period. (
) A variable work schedule must be requested in writing by the executive or his/her immediate manager in advance of its use. (
) The requester must document the reason(s) why a temporary variable work schedule is warranted. (
) Requests must be approved by the appropriate Deputy Chief Counsel (Technical or Operations). (
) Approval or disapproval of the request is at management’s discretion.

) Members of the Senior Executive Service (SES) may not elect a

) Executives who are SES members may work a variable work schedule. The variable work schedule option permits SES members to complete their biweekly work hour requirement in less than

workdays (excluding vary their times of arrival and departure, and/or vary the number of hours worked each day, (e.g. an executive anticipates that it will be necessary to work on a Saturday and/or a Sunday to deliver a critical project timely, that executive can email his/her manager describing the necessity to work and request approval of a variable work schedule). (
) The variable work schedule allows for a temporary variation in work only and should generally be granted for no more than one pay period. (
) A variable work schedule must be requested in writing by the executive or his/her immediate manager in advance of its use. (
) The requester must document the reason(s) why a temporary variable work schedule is warranted. (
) Requests must be approved by the appropriate Deputy Chief Counsel (Technical or Operations). (
) Approval or disapproval of the request is at management’s discretion.
Executives who are SES members may work a variable work schedule. The variable work schedule option permits SES members to complete their biweekly work hour requirement in less than

workdays (excluding vary their times of arrival and departure, and/or vary the number of hours worked each day, (e.g. an executive anticipates that it will be necessary to work on a Saturday and/or a Sunday to deliver a critical project timely, that executive can email his/her manager describing the necessity to work and request approval of a variable work schedule).
The variable work schedule allows for a temporary variation in work schedule only and should generally be granted for no more than one pay period.
Approval or disapproval of the request is at management’s discretion.
Personnel Administration, Training, Equal Employment Opportunity (
) The variable work schedule option must be documented in the SETR using the special alternate work schedule (AWS) “EXEC”. (
) All employees have the ability to request a work schedule option, subject the conditions described in this subsection. Work (

) To the extent possible, and recognizing that there must be attorney and coverage of Associate and field offices during hours set by management particular office, each employee may (with the approval of the employee’s line manager/approving official), elect their beginning and quitting times the following framework: a. All employees must be at work during core time b. Some employees must be at work during the normal working hours each office (
) Under all work schedule options, the core time is
a.m. to
p.m. customary lunch break must be taken during core time, as specified (
) Changes to alternative work schedule options may only be done Changes will be submitted on Form
-A, Alternative Work Schedule (AWS) Request, Office of Chief Counsel. (
) Managers have the right to restrict an employee’s election in order to adequate office coverage. (
) Grade
managers and Senior Level (SL) employees may not elect a schedule. (

) Employees who abuse the guidelines under any of the tours of duty are subject to disciplinary action (as would be true with respect to abuse of established period of duty). This would include revocation of alternative schedule options. (
) Once the work hours have been agreed upon between the employee and approving official, this becomes the employee’s permanent schedule until Hours revised by subsequent agreement. (

) Daily schedule changes on an ad hoc basis may be permitted whenever mutually agreed in advance between the approving official and the It should be understood, however, that an approving official has the right to limit use of a flexitour schedule or
schedule when the ments of the office necessitate such action. (
) The granting of deviations is at the discretion of the approving official. (
) It is the policy of the Office of Chief Counsel to make part-time opportunities available to the maximum extent possible for positions through GS-

, consistent with the Office’s resources and requirements. Such opportunities shall be made without discrimination for non-merit reason such as race, color, religion, age, gender, national political affiliation, disability, sexual orientation, marital or parental status. Office of Chief Counsel will also consider requests by managers to work part-time schedule, although such a schedule would be unusual.
30.4 Personnel Administration, Training, and Equal Employment Opportunity
The variable work schedule option must be documented in the SETR system using the special alternate work schedule (AWS) “EXEC”.
(3) Under all work schedule options, the core time is 10:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. The customary lunch break must be taken during core time, as specified above.

) Opportunities for voluntary change from full-time to part-time employment be given to employees whenever feasible. Full-time employees, however, not be required to accept part-time employment as a condition for continued employment and occupied full-time positions shall not be abolished for the purpose of converting them to part-time positions. (
) Employees who have been continuously employed on a part-time basis prior to April
, are not covered by the Federal Employees Part- time Career Employment Act of
(Pub.L. No.
). They may work ANY part-time schedule for as long as they work part-time without a break service. (
) Except as described in paragraph (
) above, part-time employment is a regularly scheduled tour of duty, set in advance, of at least
hours but no more than
hours per week. Managers have the authority to set hours for part-time employees, but the hours must be within the flexible time bands shown in Exhibit
, Tour of Duty Chart, Core Hours and Flexible All other relevant provisions of this section also apply to part-time (

) An employee desiring a change in employment from full-time to part-time should consult with the Human Resources Division for the purpose of deter- mining the effects such a change will have on their rights and benefits. (
) If an employee desires to pursue the matter, he/she should submit a Form
, Request for Change in Work Schedule from Full-Time to Part-Time ployment, to their supervisor. (

) In approving a request, management will weigh the employee’s request and the needs of the Office against the following criteria: a. Regular and peak workloads which might lend themselves to part-time schedules b. Adaptability or flexibility of the work to be performed on a part-time c. Special space and equipment requirements, if any d. Benefits to the employee (e.g., A part-time schedule would alleviate care concerns for parents, would lessen pressure of full day’s work on those with health problems, or would allow those near retirement to dis- continue work gradually.) (
) If approved, a SF
, Request for Personnel Action, must be submitted. (

) Occasional changes in the arrangement of days and hours are permissible meet the needs of the participating Office or the employee. Two general apply in making such changes: a. The new hours or days should, whenever possible, be set in advance of the workweek in which the change is to occur b. The change must be approved in advance by the manager/supervisor (
) An increase of an employee’s tour of duty above
hours per week may extend more than two consecutive pay periods. (
) A part-time employee with a tour of duty of six hours or less in a day does include a lunch period for that day. Similarly, if a part-time employee has a of duty of
or
hours in a day the tour of duty for that day should include a lunch break. Chief Counsel Directives Manual

Opportunities for voluntary change from full-time to part-time employment shall be given to employees whenever feasible. Full-time employees, however, shall not be required to accept part-time employment as a condition for continued employment and occupied full-time positions shall not be abolished for the sole purpose of converting them to part-time positions.

30.4 Personnel Administration, Training, and Equal Employment Opportunity

) Although an employee who accepts a part-time position has no right to return to a full time position, the Office will grant the request if consistent with to Full-Time workload, staffing and budget requirements and if the employee’s most recent performance rating of record is fully successful or better. (
) When an employee is returned to a full-time schedule, the employee will be returned in the same or similar position at the same grade and step.
When an employee is returned to a full-time schedule, the employee will be returned in the same or similar position at the same grade and step.
